title: Heartbeat (Imagine This!)
features: Flick-dash flick-dash! Lub-DUB. Lub-DUB. Lub-DUB. From tiny meadow mice to tall giraffes to the octopus with three hearts, each animal's heart has its own beat, in tune with its body’s needs. Strong graphic art and rhythmic text packed with interesting facts to capture imaginations.
description: K-Gr 4-This science title uses poetic verse to describe the heartbeats of several different animals. Each animal, including the pygmy shrew, the giraffe, the octopus, and the python, receives a two-page spread with a lyrical verse listing the number of times the animal's heart beats per minute. Additionally, the text provides two small pieces of information about the spotlighted animal's heart, life, or habits. Over the course of several profiles, this approach feels repetitive rather than informative. The final spread culminates in a verse explanation of the human heart followed by a prose explanation of how the heart works. A labeled illustration of a human heart allows readers to visualize the information. An author's note reveals the inspiration behind the book; resources feature books for children and adults. VERDICT A secondary purchase for most collections, except for libraries with patrons who clamor for poetry or light nonfiction on specific topics.-Brittany Drehobl, Morton Grove P.L., ILα(c) Copyright 2011. An editor and teaching artist, she often shares her love of language in arts-integrated school residencies, and she has written two travel guides about her home state of Connecticut, where the music and movement of Long Island Sound were among the first sensations she experienced. Doe is a founder of the Tassy Walden Award for New Voices in Children's Literature.

Daniel Long graduated from Norwich University of the Arts in 2014 and has been working as an illustrator in Norfolk, England, ever since. His work is heavily influenced by mid-century design, architecture, and fashion, which can be seen in his color palettes and his choice of subject matter.
